text:
*[Bug 18909] stats: stack overflow when subtracting certain time series*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18909>

Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
                 CC|                            |maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CONFIRMED
     Ever confirmed|0                           |1

--- Comment #2 from Martin Maechler (<mailto:maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch|maechler@stat.math.ethz.ch>) ---
Well, in some sense its "an inverse" of FAQ 7.31; as Prakash mentioned the
infinite loop problem happens only very rarely,
e.g., if you keep `frequency = 2*pi`, the only `n` in 1..20000
for which it happens is the `n = 711`.
.

Anyway, in such cases you always should first look at `traceback()`:
```
d <- ts(1:711, frequency=2*pi); d - d
traceback()
```
which prints ~ 2200 lines, ending with
```
18: NextMethod("[")
17: `[.ts`(xtime, (xtime < end) & ((end - 1/xfreq) < xtime))
16: xtime[(xtime < end) & ((end - 1/xfreq) < xtime)]
15: window.default(x, ...)
14: as.ts(window.default(x, ...))
13: window.ts(sers[[i]], st, en)
12: window(sers[[i]], st, en)
11: .cbind.ts(list(e1, e2), c(deparse(substitute(e1))[1L],
deparse(substitute(e2))[1L]), 
        union = FALSE)
10: Ops.ts((xtime < end), ((end - 1/xfreq) < xtime))
9: NextMethod("[")
8: `[.ts`(xtime, (xtime < end) & ((end - 1/xfreq) < xtime))
7: xtime[(xtime < end) & ((end - 1/xfreq) < xtime)]
6: window.default(x, ...)
5: as.ts(window.default(x, ...))
4: window.ts(sers[[i]], st, en)
3: window(sers[[i]], st, en)
2: .cbind.ts(list(e1, e2), c(deparse(substitute(e1))[1L],
deparse(substitute(e2))[1L]), 
       union = FALSE)
1: Ops.ts(d, d)
```
Now if I start thinking and pondering, I get to the preliminary conclusion that
almost surely we should be fixing `stats:::window.default`.
Its logic is already based on the (in)famous  `getOption("ts.eps")`  which
indeed is needed because of double precision / computer arithmetic
imperfection, i.e., yes indeed related to FAQ 7.31:
And indeed, with our `d`:
```
> window(d, 1, end = 114.1)
Error: C stack usage  9524784 is too close to the limit
```
and indeed, as I suspected, it is `ts.eps`:
```
window(d, 1, end = 114.1, ts.eps = 0.01) # works fine
```
and so do all `ts.eps` >= 7e-5 (on my platform).   
"Unfortunately", `ts.eps` is 1e-5 by default.

Note that the `ts.eps` option, including its default 1e-5, had been introduced
(for S or S+/S-PLUS) before R existed and we (R core) had used it to fix other
(double precision imperfection related) bugs, e.g., bug 17669.  It is well
possible (even probable in my book) that a thorough analysis would lead to more
careful and sophisticated settings of how and where `ts.eps` is used exactly in
the several `ts*()` functions.

Further note that in addition to `ts.eps` there are 3 places in the
`stats/R/ts.R` source file where a hardwired
 `+0.001` has been in use ("forever") before rounding.... and I'm pretty sure
that that is also not the perfect fuzz amount for all possible situations.

Ditto for the hardwired   `nobs <- floor(cycles + 1.01)`  in `ts()`  which has
been there (in file `src/library/base/R/ts` (sic!) already in svn rev 335 (from
1997-12-01, long before R 1.0.0 ...).

text:
*[Bug 7084] text(x, y, labels) - recycling problems and RFC*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=7084>

--- Comment #14 from Heather Turner (<mailto:ht@heatherturner.net|ht@heatherturner.net>) ---
Created attachment 3497
  --> <https://bugs.r-project.org/attachment.cgi?id=3497&action=edit>
patch that handles expressions as well

Patch incorporating Paul's suggestion in Comment 12.

Tested with gdiff for patched vs unpatched R-devel r88298, on examples from
grid, graphics, grDevices, lattice and ggplot2. 

ggplot2 also passes `R CMD check` with the patched R-devel, although I had to
use `_R_CHECK_FORCE_SUGGESTS_=FALSE` as I couldn't get ragg to install from
source on macOS (all other suggested packages for ggplot2 were installed). 

As this bug is unlikely to be affected by graphics device, I think this patch
is ready to be committed.

text:
*[Bug 18892] Support the use of netrc when using the libcurl downloader?*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18892>

--- Comment #8 from Kevin Ushey (<mailto:kevinushey@gmail.com|kevinushey@gmail.com>) ---
> Also it seems there have been some security vulnerabilities related to netrc files in curl (leaking secrets):

As I understand it, those vulnerabilities seem to be due to `curl` mishandling
`.netrc` files; they don't seem explicitly like deficiencies in `.netrc`
itself, per-se.

> What kind of fix did you have in mind? On Unix, the R temporary session directory where the cache is stored by default is only accessible to the user. And when the user provides a custom cache directory, the user has control over its permissions.

I was thinking something like:

- Remove the credentials from the URL before forming the file path, or
- Use a hash (SHA?) of the URL for the filename.

But given that the directory is indeed accessible only by the current user, I
think you're right that this isn't a huge deal.

I was thinking something like:

- Remove the credentials from the URL before forming the file path, or
- Use a hash (SHA?) of the URL for the filename.

But given that the directory is indeed accessible only by the current user, I
think you're right that this isn't a huge deal.
